article:
Agnipath Scheme

The Agnipath Scheme is a recruitment program launched by the Indian government in 2022 to recruit personnel below officer rank (POR) for the Indian Armed Forces. The scheme, announced on June 14, 2022, aims to transform the Indian military into a modern, tech-savvy force, with a focus on merit-based recruitment and a reduced tenure of service.

# Background
The Indian Armed Forces have been facing challenges in terms of modernization, with an aging population and a large number of personnel set to retire in the coming years. The forces have also been facing difficulties in attracting and retaining young talent, with many opting for alternative career options. The Agnipath Scheme aims to address these challenges by offering a new recruitment model that is more attractive to young Indians.

# Overview
The Agnipath Scheme offers recruitment for four years, with an option for 25% of recruits to be retained for a further 15 years. The recruits, known as "Agniveers," will undergo training and serve in various roles, including combat, technical, and administrative positions. The scheme aims to recruit 46,000 personnel in the first year, with a target of 50,000 recruits per year over the next four years.

# Reservation and welfare benefits
The Agnipath Scheme offers various benefits to recruits, including a salary package, medical facilities, and insurance coverage. The scheme also provides for reservation for ex-servicemen and their families in various government jobs and educational institutions. The government has also announced plans to provide financial assistance to Agniveers after their four-year tenure, to help them transition to civilian life.

# Criticism
The Agnipath Scheme has faced criticism from various quarters, including political parties, retired defense personnel, and state governments.

## By political parties and activists
Opposition parties have criticized the scheme, arguing that it will lead to the " contractualization" of the armed forces and undermine the morale of serving personnel. Some have also questioned the wisdom of recruiting personnel for a short tenure, arguing that it will lead to a lack of continuity and institutional memory.

## By retired defence personnel
Retired defense personnel have also expressed concerns about the scheme, arguing that it will lead to a decrease in the quality of recruits and undermine the reputation of the armed forces. Some have also questioned the government's decision to reduce the tenure of service, arguing that it will lead to a lack of experience and expertise among personnel.

## By state governments
State governments have also expressed concerns about the scheme, arguing that it will lead to a shortage of personnel in various states. Some have also questioned the government's decision to reserve 25% of recruits for a further 15 years, arguing that it will lead to a lack of opportunities for new recruits.

## Data on employment of veterans
Data on the employment of veterans has also raised concerns about the effectiveness of the scheme. According to various reports, a large number of ex-servicemen are struggling to find employment after leaving the armed forces, with many facing difficulties in adjusting to civilian life.

# Protests
The Agnipath Scheme has faced widespread protests across the country, with many young Indians taking to the streets to express their opposition to the scheme.

## Bharat Bandh (All India Strike)
The protests began with a Bharat Bandh (All India Strike) on June 20, 2022, with many opposition parties and trade unions participating in the strike. The strike led to widespread disruptions across the country, with many trains and buses being cancelled or delayed.

## 21 June onwards
The protests continued on June 21, 2022, with many young Indians taking to the streets to express their opposition to the scheme. The protests turned violent in many places, with many police personnel and protesters being injured.

# Response by the Government
The government has responded to the protests by announcing various concessions and incentives for Agniveers. The government has also announced plans to increase the tenure of service for Agniveers, from four years to five years.

# Plea in the Supreme Court against the scheme
A plea has been filed in the Supreme Court against the Agnipath Scheme, arguing that it is unconstitutional and violative of the fundamental rights of citizens. The court has yet to hear the plea.

# First Agniveer batch (2023)
The first batch of Agniveers is set to commence training in 2023, with many young Indians having already been recruited under the scheme.

## Hyderabad
The first batch of Agniveers will commence training at the Air Force Academy in Hyderabad, with many young Indians having already reported for duty.

## Nashik
The second batch of Agniveers will commence training at the Artillery Centre in Nashik, with many young Indians having already reported for duty.

## Ranikhet
The third batch of Agniveers will commence training at the Kumaon Regimental Centre in Ranikhet, with many young Indians having already reported for duty.

# Amendment in recruitment procedure
The government has announced plans to amend the recruitment procedure for Agniveers, to make it more transparent and merit-based.

* Ministry of Defence (India)
* Recruitment in the Indian Armed Forces

Killing of Nahel Merzouk

The killing of Nahel Merzouk was a high-profile incident that occurred on June 27, 2023, in Nanterre, a suburb of Paris, France. The event sparked widespread outrage, protests, and debates about police brutality, racism, and immigration in France. This article provides an overview of the incident, its background, and the subsequent reactions.

# Background

Nanterre is a commune in the Hauts-de-Seine department in the ÃŽle-de-France region of northern France. The area has a diverse population, with a significant proportion of residents from immigrant backgrounds. Tensions between law enforcement and the local community have been reported in the past, with some residents accusing the police of racial profiling and heavy-handedness.

# Victim

Nahel Merzouk was a 17-year-old French teenager of Algerian descent. He was a student at a local high school and was known to his friends and family as a calm and reserved individual. Merzouk was also an avid soccer player and had a passion for music.

# Shooting

On June 27, 2023, Nahel Merzouk was shot and killed by a police officer in Nanterre. The circumstances surrounding the shooting are disputed, with different accounts emerging from the prosecution, police, and witnesses.

## Prosecution version

According to the prosecution, Merzouk was driving a car with two passengers when he was stopped by police for a traffic violation. The officers alleged that Merzouk attempted to flee the scene, and one of the officers fired a warning shot into the air. The prosecution claims that Merzouk then accelerated the car towards the officer, who fired a second shot that hit Merzouk in the chest.

## Police version challenged by a video

However, a video of the incident, captured by a bystander, appears to contradict the police account. The video shows the police car pulling over Merzouk's vehicle, and the officers approaching the car with their guns drawn. The video then shows one of the officers firing a shot into the car, followed by Merzouk's vehicle slowly rolling forward before coming to a stop. The video does not show Merzouk accelerating the car towards the officer.

## Version from the third passenger

One of the passengers in Merzouk's car, who wishes to remain anonymous, has provided a different account of the events. According to this witness, Merzouk was stopped by police for a minor traffic infraction, and the officers became aggressive and began yelling at Merzouk. The witness claims that Merzouk attempted to explain himself, but the officers continued to escalate the situation, eventually leading to the shooting.

# Investigation

The incident is currently under investigation by the French authorities, including the National Police Inspectorate General (IGPN) and the Paris prosecutor's office. The investigation is ongoing, and no official conclusions have been reached.

# Initial reactions

The killing of Nahel Merzouk sparked widespread outrage and condemnation from the local community, civil rights groups, and politicians.

## Polemics on immigration

The incident has also reignited debates about immigration and racism in France. Some politicians and commentators have linked the shooting to issues of immigration and crime, while others have argued that the incident is a symptom of a broader problem of police brutality and systemic racism.

# Unrest

In the days following the shooting, protests and unrest broke out in Nanterre and other suburbs of Paris. Demonstrators clashed with police, and several businesses and vehicles were damaged. The unrest has since subsided, but tensions remain high in the community.

# See also

* Police brutality in France
* Racism in France
* Immigration to France

# Notes

This article is based on publicly available information and may not reflect the full complexity of the incident.

article:
Fenwick Tree
================

A Fenwick tree, also known as a binary indexed tree, is a data structure used to efficiently calculate prefix sums and range sums in an array. It was first described by Peter Fenwick in 1994. The Fenwick tree is particularly useful in scenarios where the array is frequently updated and queried, as it allows for both operations to be performed in logarithmic time.

Motivation
-----------

When dealing with large arrays, calculating prefix sums or range sums can be a computationally expensive operation. A naive approach would involve iterating over the entire array, resulting in a time complexity of O(n). This can be impractical for large datasets or applications where speed is critical. The Fenwick tree addresses this issue by providing a data structure that can efficiently calculate prefix sums and range sums in logarithmic time.

Description
-----------

A Fenwick tree is a tree-like data structure that consists of nodes, each representing a range of values in the original array. The tree is constructed by dividing the array into smaller segments, with each segment represented by a node in the tree. The value stored in each node is the cumulative sum of the values in its corresponding segment.

### The Interrogation Tree

The interrogation tree is a tree-like structure that represents the segments of the original array. Each node in the interrogation tree corresponds to a segment of the array and stores the cumulative sum of the values in that segment. The interrogation tree is used to calculate prefix sums and range sums by traversing the tree and accumulating the values in the nodes.

### The Update Tree

The update tree is a companion tree to the interrogation tree. It is used to update the values in the original array by propagating the changes through the tree. The update tree is essential for maintaining the integrity of the Fenwick tree when the underlying array is modified.

### The Search Tree

The search tree is a tree-like structure that represents the ranges of values in the original array. Each node in the search tree corresponds to a range of values and stores the cumulative sum of the values in that range. The search tree is used to calculate range sums by traversing the tree and accumulating the values in the nodes.

Pseudocode
----------

The following pseudocode illustrates the construction of a Fenwick tree:
```
function constructFenwickTree(arr):
  n = length(arr)
  tree = new array of size n + 1
  for i from 1 to n:
    tree[i] = arr[i]
  for i from 1 to n:
    j = i + (i & -i)
    if j <= n:
      tree[j] += tree[i]
  return tree
```
This pseudocode constructs a Fenwick tree by initializing the tree with the values from the original array and then propagating the values through the tree using the update tree.

Construction
------------

The construction of a Fenwick tree involves the following steps:

1. Initialize the tree with the values from the original array.
2. Propagate the values through the tree using the update tree.
3. Calculate the prefix sums and range sums using the interrogation tree and search tree.

See also
--------

* Prefix sum
* Range sum
* Binary indexed tree
* Cumulative sum

References
----------

* Fenwick, P. (1994). "A new data structure for cumulative frequency tables". Software: Practice and Experience, 24(3), 327-336.
* Bender, M. A., & Farach-Colton, M. (2000). "The LCA problem revisited". Proceedings of the 4th Latin American Symposium on Theoretical Informatics, 88-94.

External links
---------------

* Wikipedia: Range sum

article:
Everything Everywhere All at Once

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a 2022 American absurdist science fiction film written and directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, collectively known as the Daniels. The film stars Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan, Jenny Slate, and Jamie Lee Curtis, and follows the story of a Chinese-American woman who discovers she can access parallel universes.

# Plot

The film follows Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh), a middle-aged Chinese-American woman who is struggling to balance her life. She is being audited by the IRS, her laundromat business is failing, and she is on the verge of divorcing her husband, Waymond (Ke Huy Quan). During an audit meeting, Evelyn is suddenly thrust into a multiverse, where she can access parallel universes and alternate versions of herself.

As Evelyn navigates the multiverse, she encounters various versions of herself, each living different lives. She must also confront a powerful villain known as "Jobu Tupaki," who is threatening the fabric of the multiverse. Along the way, Evelyn discovers that she has the ability to "verse-jump," allowing her to access different parallel universes and switch between them seamlessly.

With the help of her husband and a group of allies from different universes, Evelyn must stop Jobu Tupaki and save the multiverse. Along the way, she must also confront her own personal demons and learn to accept herself and her place in the world.

# Cast

* Michelle Yeoh as Evelyn Wang
* Ke Huy Quan as Waymond Wang
* Jenny Slate as Big Nose
* Jamie Lee Curtis as Deirdre Beaubeirdre
* Stephanie Hsu as Joy Wang / Jobu Tupaki
* Harry Shum Jr. as Chad
* Tallie Medel as Becky
* Audrey Wasilewski as Alpha

# Production

## Development

The idea for Everything Everywhere All at Once was born out of a conversation between Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, who were brainstorming ideas for a film. Kwan had been fascinated by the concept of the multiverse, and Scheinert had been experimenting with absurd humor in his previous work. The two filmmakers combined their ideas and began writing the script, which would eventually become Everything Everywhere All at Once.

## Casting

Michelle Yeoh was the first actress to be cast in the film, and she was a major draw for the project. Yeoh had previously worked with the Daniels on their 2016 film Swiss Army Man, and she was eager to collaborate with them again. Ke Huy Quan, who had previously appeared in films such as The Goonies and Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, was cast as Waymond Wang, Evelyn's husband.

## Filming

Principal photography for Everything Everywhere All at Once began in January 2020 and lasted for 38 days. The film was shot on location in California and Georgia, with additional scenes filmed in Los Angeles and Hong Kong. The Daniels used a combination of practical and visual effects to create the film's elaborate action sequences and multiverse scenes.

## Visual effects

The visual effects for Everything Everywhere All at Once were created by a team of artists and technicians led by Zak Stoltz and Ethan Feldbau. The team used a combination of computer-generated imagery (CGI) and practical effects to create the film's elaborate action sequences and multiverse scenes. The film's visual effects were praised by critics, who noted their creativity and originality.

# Themes

Everything Everywhere All at Once explores a number of themes, including identity, existentialism, and the multiverse. The film's protagonist, Evelyn Wang, is a complex and multifaceted character who is struggling to find her place in the world. Through her journey, the film explores the idea of identity and how it is shaped by our experiences and relationships.

The film also explores the concept of the multiverse, which is used as a metaphor for the infinite possibilities and choices that we face in life. The film's use of the multiverse allows the Daniels to explore different genres and styles, from action and comedy to drama and science fiction.

# Music

The score for Everything Everywhere All at Once was composed by Son Lux, a band that has previously collaborated with the Daniels on their film Swiss Army Man. The score features a combination of electronic and orchestral elements, and it was praised by critics for its creativity and originality. The film's soundtrack also features a number of songs by artists such as Mitski and David Bowie.

# Release

## Theatrical

Everything Everywhere All at Once was released in the United States on March 25, 2022, by A24. The film received a limited release, opening in 10 theaters in New York and Los Angeles. The film expanded to additional theaters in the following weeks, and it eventually played in over 2,000 theaters across the United States.

## Home media

Everything Everywhere All at Once was released on home media on June 7, 2022, by A24 and Lionsgate. The film was released on DVD, Blu-ray, and digital platforms, and it featured a number of bonus features, including deleted scenes and a behind-the-scenes documentary.

# Reception

## Box office

Everything Everywhere All at Once was a commercial success, grossing over $140 million at the box office worldwide. The film's success was driven by positive word-of-mouth and critical acclaim, and it became one of the highest-grossing independent films of 2022.

## Critical response

Everything Everywhere All at Once received widespread critical acclaim, with many critics praising its originality, creativity, and performances. The film holds a 95% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on over 200 reviews, with an average rating of 8.6/10. The critical consensus on the site reads: "Everything Everywhere All at Once is a wildly inventive and visually stunning film that is full of surprises and delights."

## Legacy

Everything Everywhere All at Once has been recognized as a landmark film in the science fiction genre, and it has been praised for its originality and creativity. The film's success has also helped to establish the Daniels as major talents in the film industry, and it has paved the way for future projects.

## Accolades

Everything Everywhere All at Once has received a number of awards and nominations, including several Independent Spirit Awards and a Critics' Choice Movie Award. The film's cast, including Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan, have also received critical acclaim and have been recognized with several awards and nominations.

* The film's title is a reference to the concept of the multiverse, which is explored in the film.

2022 T20 Blast

The 2022 T20 Blast was the 20th season of the T20 Blast, a professional Twenty20 cricket league in England and Wales. The tournament featured 18 teams, divided into two groups of nine teams each. The season began on May 25, 2022, and concluded on July 16, 2022.

# Format

The 2022 T20 Blast followed the same format as the previous season. The 18 teams were divided into two groups of nine teams each, with each team playing 14 group stage matches. The top four teams from each group qualified for the quarter-finals, with the winners advancing to the Finals Day. The Finals Day consisted of two semi-finals and the final, with the winner crowned the 2022 T20 Blast champion.

# Teams

2022 NBA Playoffs

The 2022 NBA playoffs was the postseason tournament of the National Basketball Association's 2021-22 season. The playoffs began on April 16, 2022, and concluded on June 16, 2022.

# Overview

The 2022 NBA playoffs featured 16 teams competing in a best-of-series tournament format, with the conference champions advancing to the NBA Finals. The playoffs were played in a standard format, with the top eight teams from each conference qualifying for the playoffs.

## Notable updates to postseason appearances

The 2022 NBA playoffs saw several teams make notable updates to their postseason appearances. The Memphis Grizzlies made their first playoff appearance since 2017, while the Minnesota Timberwolves made their first playoff appearance since 2018. The Brooklyn Nets, who had been eliminated in the first round of the 2021 playoffs, made a strong push for the playoffs but ultimately fell short.

## Notable occurrences

The 2022 NBA playoffs were marked by several notable occurrences. The Phoenix Suns, who had been one of the top teams in the Western Conference all season, were eliminated in the second round by the Dallas Mavericks. The Golden State Warriors, who had been struggling with injuries all season, made a surprise run to the NBA Finals, where they ultimately defeated the Boston Celtics.

# Format

The 2022 NBA playoffs were played in a best-of-series tournament format, with each series featuring a best-of-seven format. The playoffs were divided into four rounds: the first round, conference semifinals, conference finals, and the NBA Finals.

# Playoff qualifying

article:
University of Miami

The University of Miami is a private research university located in Coral Gables, Florida. Founded in 1925, the university is known for its academic excellence, research opportunities, and athletic programs. With a diverse student body and faculty, the University of Miami is a leading institution in the United States.

#History

The University of Miami was founded in 1925 by a group of citizens who wanted to establish a university in the Miami area. The university's first classes were held on October 15, 1926, with 372 students and 27 faculty members. The university's early years were marked by significant growth and development, with the establishment of new colleges and programs.

##Leadership

The University of Miami has had several notable leaders throughout its history. Some of the most notable include:

###Bowman Foster Ashe (1926 to 1952)

Bowman Foster Ashe was the first president of the University of Miami. He served from 1926 to 1952 and played a crucial role in establishing the university's early programs and colleges.

###Jay F. W. Pearson (1952 until 1962)

Jay F. W. Pearson was the second president of the University of Miami. He served from 1952 to 1962 and oversaw significant growth and development at the university.

###Henry King Stanford (1962 until 1981)

Henry King Stanford was the third president of the University of Miami. He served from 1962 to 1981 and played a key role in establishing the university's research programs.

###Edward T. Foote II (1981 until 2000)

Edward T. Foote II was the fourth president of the University of Miami. He served from 1981 to 2000 and oversaw significant growth and development at the university.

###Donna Shalala (2000 until 2015)

Donna Shalala was the fifth president of the University of Miami. She served from 2000 to 2015 and played a key role in establishing the university's research programs and community engagement initiatives.

###Julio Frenk (2015 until 2024)

Julio Frenk is the sixth president of the University of Miami. He has served since 2015 and has overseen significant growth and development at the university.

#Campus

The University of Miami has several campuses located throughout the Miami area. The main campus is located in Coral Gables, with additional campuses in the Miami Health District and on Virginia Key.

##Coral Gables campus

The Coral Gables campus is the main campus of the University of Miami. It is located on 239 acres of land and features a mix of modern and historic buildings. The campus is home to many of the university's colleges and programs, including the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Business Administration, and the School of Communication.

###Student housing

The University of Miami offers several student housing options on the Coral Gables campus. These include residence halls, apartment-style living, and fraternity and sorority houses.

##Medical school campus

The University of Miami's medical school campus is located in the Miami Health District. The campus is home to the Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine, as well as several research centers and institutes.

##Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science campus

The Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science campus is located on Virginia Key. The campus is home to the Rosenstiel School, as well as several research centers and institutes.

##South and Richmond campuses

The University of Miami also has campuses located in the cities of Homestead and Richmond. These campuses offer a range of programs and services, including continuing education and community outreach initiatives.

##Libraries

The University of Miami has several libraries located throughout its campuses. The main library is the Otto G. Richter Library, which is located on the Coral Gables campus. The library offers a range of resources and services, including research assistance, study spaces, and access to online databases.

#Academics

The University of Miami offers a range of academic programs, including undergraduate and graduate degrees. The university is known for its academic excellence, research opportunities, and community engagement initiatives.

##Accreditations

The University of Miami is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges (SACSCOC). The university's programs are also accredited by a range of specialized accrediting agencies, including the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) and the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE).

##Undergraduate admissions

The University of Miami is a highly selective institution, with an acceptance rate of around 32%. The university uses a holistic admissions process, considering a range of factors including academic performance, standardized test scores, and extracurricular activities.

##Organization

The University of Miami is organized into several colleges and schools, including the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Business Administration, and the School of Communication. The university also offers a range of interdisciplinary programs and centers, including the Center for Computational Science and the Institute for Bioethics and Health Policy.

##Attendance costs

The University of Miami is a private institution, and tuition and fees are around $52,000 per year. The university also offers a range of financial aid and scholarship programs, including need-based and merit-based aid.

##Rankings

The University of Miami is ranked among the top universities in the United States, according to a range of rankings and ratings. The university is ranked #44 in the National Universities category by U.S. News & World Report, and #1 in the Top Private Universities in Florida category by Niche.

##Research

The University of Miami is a research-intensive institution, with a range of research centers and institutes. The university is classified as a "Highest Research Activity" institution by the Carnegie Foundation, and is a member of the prestigious Association of American Universities (AAU).

#Student life

The University of Miami offers a range of student life programs and services, including student organizations, recreational sports, and cultural events. The university is also home to a diverse and vibrant student body, with students from all 50 states and over 100 countries.

#Athletics

The University of Miami's athletic teams, known as the Hurricanes, compete in the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I. The university offers a range of sports programs, including football, baseball, and basketball.

##Football

The University of Miami's football team has a long and storied history, with five national championships and 12 conference championships. The team plays its home games at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens.

##Baseball

The University of Miami's baseball team has won four national championships and 25 conference championships. The team plays its home games at Alex Rodriguez Park at Mark Light Field on the Coral Gables campus.

##Men's and women's basketball

The University of Miami's men's and women's basketball teams compete in the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC). The teams play their home games at the Watsco Center on the Coral Gables campus.

##Men's and women's tennis

The University of Miami's men's and women's tennis teams compete in the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC). The teams play their home matches at the Neil Schiff Tennis Center on the Coral Gables campus.

##Other sports

The University of Miami also offers a range of other sports programs, including volleyball, soccer, and track and field.

#People

The University of Miami has a long and distinguished history of producing notable alumni and faculty.

##Notable alumni

Some of the university's most notable alumni include:

* Gloria Estefan, singer and songwriter
* Anderson Cooper, journalist and television personality
* Danny Pino, actor
* Dwyane Wade, professional basketball player

##Notable faculty

Some of the university's most notable faculty members include:

* Neil deGrasse Tyson, astrophysicist and science communicator
* Robin Farquhar, economist and former president of the University of Manitoba
* Michael Hammer, business consultant and author

article:
J. Robert Oppenheimer

Julius Robert Oppenheimer, known as J. Robert Oppenheimer, was a renowned American theoretical physicist and director of the Manhattan Project, the secret research and development project that produced the atomic bomb during World War II. He is often referred to as the "father of the atomic bomb" for his role in the project. Oppenheimer was a complex figure, whose life was marked by both scientific brilliance and personal turmoil.

#Early life

##Childhood and education

Oppenheimer was born on April 22, 1904, in New York City, to Ella and Julius Oppenheimer. His father, a textile importer, was of German Jewish descent, while his mother was a painter. Oppenheimer's early life was marked by a love for learning and a curiosity about the natural world. He attended the Ethical Culture School in New York, where he excelled in mathematics and science.

##Studies in Europe

In 1921, Oppenheimer traveled to Europe to study at the University of Cambridge, where he was accepted into the prestigious Cavendish Laboratory. However, he soon became disillusioned with the laboratory's emphasis on experimental physics and transferred to the University of GÃ¶ttingen in Germany, where he studied theoretical physics under the guidance of Max Born. Oppenheimer's time in Europe had a profound impact on his intellectual development, and he became fluent in several languages, including German, French, and Dutch.

#Early career

##Teaching

In 1929, Oppenheimer returned to the United States and began teaching at the University of California, Berkeley, where he became a popular lecturer and developed a reputation as a brilliant instructor. He also taught at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) and the University of Chicago. Oppenheimer's teaching style was characterized by his enthusiasm, his ability to explain complex concepts in simple terms, and his willingness to challenge his students.

##Scientific work

Oppenheimer's research during the 1920s and 1930s focused on quantum mechanics and relativity. He made significant contributions to the field of atomic physics, including the development of the Oppenheimer-Phillips process, which describes the interaction between an atomic nucleus and an electron. Oppenheimer also worked on the theory of black holes and was one of the first scientists to propose the existence of neutron stars.

#Private and political life

##Politics

Oppenheimer's politics were shaped by his experiences during the Great Depression and the rise of fascism in Europe. He became increasingly interested in left-wing politics and was a member of several organizations, including the American Communist Party. However, Oppenheimer's involvement with communism was largely intellectual, and he never became a committed party member.

##Relationships and children

In 1940, Oppenheimer married Katherine "Kitty" Posen, a former communist and a woman with a troubled past. The couple had two children, Toni and Peter. Oppenheimer's relationships with his family members were often strained, and he struggled to balance his personal and professional life.

##Mysticism

Oppenheimer had a deep interest in Eastern mysticism and philosophy, particularly Hinduism and Buddhism. He saw parallels between the principles of physics and the principles of Eastern thought, and he often incorporated mystical ideas into his lectures and writings.

#Manhattan Project

##Los Alamos

In 1942, Oppenheimer was recruited to lead the Manhattan Project, a secret research and development project that aimed to produce an atomic bomb. Oppenheimer was chosen for his exceptional leadership skills, his knowledge of physics, and his ability to bring together a team of talented scientists. The project was based in Los Alamos, New Mexico, where Oppenheimer established a research community that became known for its intensity and creativity.

##Bomb design

Oppenheimer played a crucial role in the design of the atomic bomb, working closely with scientists such as Enrico Fermi and Ernest Lawrence. He was responsible for overseeing the development of the bomb's physics package, which included the design of the nuclear reactor and the development of the plutonium core.

##Trinity

On July 16, 1945, Oppenheimer witnessed the first nuclear test, codenamed Trinity, which was conducted in the desert near Alamogordo, New Mexico. The test was a success, and Oppenheimer was overcome with emotion as he watched the mushroom cloud rise into the sky.

#Postwar activities

##Institute for Advanced Study

After the war, Oppenheimer became the director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, where he established a community of scholars that included some of the most prominent scientists and thinkers of the time.

##Atomic Energy Commission

In 1947, Oppenheimer was appointed to the Atomic Energy Commission, where he played a key role in shaping the United States' nuclear energy policy. He was a strong advocate for international cooperation and arms control, and he worked tirelessly to promote the peaceful use of nuclear energy.

##Panels and study groups

Oppenheimer was a member of several panels and study groups, including the General Advisory Committee of the Atomic Energy Commission and the Scientific Advisory Panel of the Office of Defense Mobilization. He used these positions to promote his vision of a more peaceful and cooperative world.

##Security hearing

In 1954, Oppenheimer's security clearance was revoked due to his past associations with communism and his opposition to the development of the hydrogen bomb. The decision was widely criticized, and Oppenheimer's reputation was severely damaged.

#Final years

##Enrico Fermi Award

In 1963, Oppenheimer was awarded the Enrico Fermi Award, the highest honor given by the United States government for exceptional contribution to the development of nuclear energy.

#Death

Oppenheimer died on February 18, 1967, at the age of 62, due to complications from throat cancer.

#Legacy

Oppenheimer's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He will be remembered as a brilliant scientist, a charismatic leader, and a passionate advocate for peace and cooperation. His work on the Manhattan Project changed the course of history, and his contributions to the development of nuclear energy continue to shape our world today.

#Publications

Oppenheimer was a prolific writer and published numerous papers and articles on physics, philosophy, and politics. Some of his notable publications include:

* "The Meaning of Security" (1947)
* "Physics in the Contemporary World" (1947)
* "Prospects in the Arts and Sciences" (1952)
* "The Flying Trapeze: Three Crises for Physicists" (1964)

#Notes

This article is a comprehensive overview of J. Robert Oppenheimer's life and work. It is based on a wide range of sources, including Oppenheimer's own writings, biographies, and historical accounts.

#References

This article does not include references or citations. For a list of sources, see below.

#Further reading

##Books

article:
Wangaratta Football Club

The Wangaratta Football Club, also known as the Wangaratta Magpies, is a semi-professional Australian rules football club based in Wangaratta, Victoria. The club competes in the Ovens and Murray Football League (OMFL), which is one of the premier regional Australian rules football competitions in Victoria.

# Club History

The Wangaratta Football Club was established in 1874, making it one of the oldest football clubs in Victoria. The club has a rich and storied history, with numerous premierships and notable players contributing to its success over the years. The club's home ground is the Wangaratta Showgrounds, which has a seating capacity of approximately 5,000 spectators.

## Early Years (1874-1900)

The Wangaratta Football Club was formed in 1874 by a group of local sports enthusiasts. The club's early years were marked by competition in local and regional football competitions, including the Wangaratta District Football Association. In 1880, the club joined the Ovens and Murray Football Association, which later became the Ovens and Murray Football League.

## Golden Era (1900-1945)

The early 20th century was a golden era for the Wangaratta Football Club. During this period, the club won several premierships, including the 1905, 1911, and 1923 OMFL premierships. The club also produced several notable players, including Jack "Dookie" McKenzie, who played for the club from 1905 to 1915 and was a key figure in the club's success during this period.

## Post-War Era (1945-1980)

Following World War II, the Wangaratta Football Club experienced a period of rebuilding and consolidation. The club continued to compete in the OMFL and won several premierships, including the 1952 and 1962 premierships. The club also produced several notable players during this period, including Laurie "Blue" Nelson, who played for the club from 1947 to 1959 and was a key figure in the club's success during this period.

## Modern Era (1980-Present)

In the 1980s, the Wangaratta Football Club experienced a period of decline, with the club struggling to compete with other teams in the OMFL. However, in the 1990s, the club began to rebuild and has since become a competitive force in the OMFL. The club has won several premierships, including the 2008 and 2017 premierships, and has produced several notable players, including Shane Wakelin, who played for the club from 2005 to 2015 and was a key figure in the club's success during this period.

article:
Finlandâ€“NATO relations

Finland's relationship with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) has been a topic of significant interest and debate in the country's foreign policy for several decades. From its post-World War II neutrality to its current membership in the alliance, Finland's interactions with NATO have been shaped by its geographic location, historical experiences, and evolving security environment.

# History

## Background: Finnish neutrality at the end of World War II

Following World War II, Finland found itself in a unique position, having fought two wars against the Soviet Union â€“ the Winter War (1939-1940) and the Continuation War (1941-1944). The country's relationship with the Soviet Union was formalized through the 1948 Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual Assistance, which included a mutual defense commitment. To maintain good relations with the Soviet Union and avoid being drawn into the emerging Cold War, Finland declared itself neutral, a stance that would shape its foreign policy for decades to come.

## 1949â€“2023: Pre-membership relations

### 1949â€“1991: Finnish neutrality during the Cold War

Throughout the Cold War, Finland maintained its policy of neutrality, carefully balancing its relationships with the Soviet Union and the Western bloc. The country participated in various international organizations, such as the United Nations, and engaged in diplomatic efforts to promote dÃ©tente and disarmament. Although Finland was not a member of the Warsaw Pact or NATO, it developed close economic and cultural ties with Western Europe, particularly with Sweden and other Nordic countries.

### 1991â€“1995: Immediate aftermath of the Cold War

The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 marked a significant turning point in Finland's foreign policy. As the country began to reassess its security environment, it started to explore new avenues for cooperation with Western countries. In 1992, Finland joined the Western European Union (WEU) as an observer and began to participate in various NATO activities, such as the North Atlantic Cooperation Council (NACC). However, the country's non-alignment policy remained in place, and NATO membership was not considered a viable option.

### 1995â€“2022: Shift from non-alignment within the European Union

Finland's accession to the European Union (EU) in 1995 marked a significant shift in its foreign policy. As a member of the EU, Finland began to participate in the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). While maintaining its non-aligned status, Finland engaged in various EU-led crisis management operations and developed close relationships with other EU member states. However, the country's relationship with NATO remained limited, and membership was not considered a priority.

### 2022â€“2023: Accession process following the Russian invasion of Ukraine

The Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 marked a significant turning point in Finland's relationship with NATO. As the country began to reassess its security environment, it started to explore the possibility of NATO membership.

#### February â€“ May 2022: Initial response to the invasion

In the immediate aftermath of the invasion, Finland condemned Russia's actions and began to provide humanitarian assistance to Ukraine. The country also started to enhance its defense capabilities, including increasing its military spending and engaging in joint exercises with NATO member states.

#### May â€“ June 2022: Declaration of intent, application

On May 12, 2022, Finland's parliament voted in favor of a proposal to consider NATO membership. President Sauli NiinistÃ¶ and Prime Minister Sanna Marin announced that the country would submit an application to join NATO, which was formally submitted on May 18, 2022.

#### June 2022 â€“ April 2023: Ratification

Following the submission of its application, Finland's accession process entered a new phase. The country's parliament approved the accession treaty on March 1, 2023, and the treaty was ratified by all 30 NATO member states on April 4, 2023.

## 2023â€“present: Finnish membership in NATO

On April 4, 2023, Finland officially became the 31st member of NATO, marking a significant shift in the country's foreign and security policy. As a member of the alliance, Finland is committed to collective defense and will participate in NATO's decision-making processes.

# Finland's foreign relations with other NATO member states

Finland's participation in NATO's collective defense commitment will also require the country to engage in joint military exercises and operations with other member states.

The operation marked the culmination of years of efforts by U.S. intelligence agencies to track down and neutralize the elusive terrorist leader.

He was a founding member of the Egyptian Islamic Jihad and later merged the group with al-Qaeda, becoming bin Laden's deputy. Following the 9/11 attacks in 2001, al-Zawahiri played a crucial role in reorganizing and rebranding al-Qaeda, helping the group to adapt to the changing global security landscape.

In 2011, al-Zawahiri took over as the leader of al-Qaeda after bin Laden's death in a U.S. raid in Abbottabad, Pakistan. Under his leadership, the group continued to wage a global insurgency, carrying out attacks in various regions, including the Middle East, North Africa, and South Asia.

article:
Illegal Operation (Euphemism)

An "illegal operation" is a euphemism that was commonly used in the United States during the early to mid-20th century to refer to an abortion. This term was employed to avoid direct mention of the procedure, which was often stigmatized and subject to various laws and social taboos. The phrase was frequently used in medical and journalistic contexts to convey the nature of the operation without explicitly stating it.

# History

The history of the "illegal operation" euphemism is deeply intertwined with the complex and often contentious history of abortion in the United States.

## Background

During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, abortion was increasingly criminalized in the United States, with many states passing laws that prohibited the procedure. As a result, the topic became highly stigmatized, and direct references to abortion were often avoided in polite conversation and public discourse.

## "The thing that had no name"

In the early 20th century, the term "illegal operation" emerged as a way to refer to abortion without directly stating it. This phrase was often used in medical and journalistic contexts, where it was necessary to convey the nature of the procedure without explicitly mentioning it. The term was also used in popular culture, such as in film and literature, to hint at the existence of abortion without explicitly depicting it.

## Abortion euphemism elsewhere in print

The use of euphemisms to refer to abortion was not unique to the United States. In other countries, such as the United Kingdom and Canada, similar phrases were used to avoid direct references to the procedure. For example, in the UK, the term "unlawful operation" was commonly used, while in Canada, the phrase "criminal operation" was employed.

# Law

The use of the "illegal operation" euphemism was also influenced by the legal status of abortion in the United States. During the mid-20th century, many states had laws that prohibited abortion, except in cases where the mother's life was at risk. As a result, the phrase was often used in legal contexts to refer to the procedure without explicitly stating it.

In the 1960s and 1970s, the legal status of abortion began to change, with several states liberalizing their laws to allow for the procedure in certain circumstances. The landmark Supreme Court case of Roe v. Wade (1973) further changed the legal landscape, establishing a woman's right to an abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy.

# Art

The "illegal operation" euphemism has also been used in various art forms, including film, television, sculpture, and fiction.

## Film

In film, the phrase was often used to hint at the existence of abortion without explicitly depicting it. For example, in the 1934 film "Of Human Bondage," the protagonist's girlfriend is shown to be recovering from an "illegal operation," which is implied to be an abortion.

## Television

In television, the phrase was also used to avoid direct references to abortion. For example, in the 1960s TV series "Dr. Kildare," a character is shown to be recovering from an "illegal operation," which is implied to be an abortion.

## Sculpture

In sculpture, the phrase has been used to create works that reference the history of abortion. For example, the artist Judy Chicago created a sculpture titled "The Dinner Party" (1974-1979), which features a plate dedicated to the history of abortion, including the use of the "illegal operation" euphemism.

## Fiction

In fiction, the phrase has been used to explore the complexities of abortion and the experiences of women who have undergone the procedure. For example, in the novel "The Girls" by Emma Cline (2016), the protagonist is shown to be considering an abortion, which is referred to as an "illegal operation."

Overall, the "illegal operation" euphemism has played a significant role in the history of abortion in the United States, reflecting the complex and often contentious nature of the issue. While the phrase is no longer commonly used, it remains an important part of the cultural and historical record, serving as a reminder of the ongoing struggles and debates surrounding abortion.

article:
Gujarat Titans
================

The Gujarat Titans are a professional Twenty20 cricket franchise based in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India. The team was founded in 2021 and is one of the two new teams introduced in the Indian Premier League (IPL) in 2022, along with the Lucknow Super Giants.

Franchise History
-----------------

The Gujarat Titans were established in 2021 after the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) announced the introduction of two new teams in the IPL. The team was purchased by the CVC Capital Partners for â‚¹5,625 crore (US$750 million). The team's name, logo, and jersey were unveiled on February 9, 2022.

Team History
-------------

The Gujarat Titans began their IPL journey in 2022, playing their first match against the Lucknow Super Giants on March 28, 2022. The team finished their inaugural season in fifth place, failing to qualify for the playoffs.

Team Identity
----------------

The Gujarat Titans' logo features a shield with a lion's head, symbolizing strength and courage. The team's colors are blue and orange, representing the state's rich cultural heritage and vibrant spirit. The team's jersey features a unique design, with a lion's mane pattern on the sleeves and a bold, blue and orange color scheme.

Home Ground
-------------

The Gujarat Titans play their home matches at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad, which is also known as the Motera Stadium. The stadium has a seating capacity of over 132,000, making it the largest stadium in the world. The stadium features state-of-the-art facilities and a unique design, with a roof that resembles a lotus flower.

Kit Manufacturers and Sponsors
------------------------------

The Gujarat Titans' kit is manufactured by the sportswear company, Ashirwad. The team's main sponsors include the CVC Capital Partners, the Adani Group, and the Gujarat Tourism Corporation.

article:
Kirstie Alley
================

Kirstie Alley was an American actress, comedian, and spokesmodel. She is best known for her roles as Rebecca Howe on the NBC sitcom "Cheers," for which she won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe Award, and as the lead character on the sitcom "Veronica's Closet," for which she won another Emmy Award.

Early Life and Education
-------------------------

Kirstie Alley was born on January 12, 1951, in Wichita, Kansas, to Robert Deal Alley, who owned a lumber company, and Lillian Alley. She was raised in a Methodist household with her two siblings, Colette and Craig. Alley developed an interest in acting at a young age and attended Wichita Southeast High School, where she was a cheerleader.

After high school, Alley attended Wichita State University, but dropped out after her sophomore year to pursue a career in interior design. However, she soon became interested in Scientology and moved to Los Angeles to work as an interior designer and to pursue her newfound faith.

Career
--------

Alley's early career in acting began with small roles on television shows and in films. Her breakthrough role came in 1982 when she played the role of Lieutenant Junior Grade Saavik in the film "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan." She then went on to play the role of Rebecca Howe on the NBC sitcom "Cheers," for which she won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe Award.

In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Alley appeared in several films, including "Look Who's Talking" and its sequels, "Look Who's Talking Too" and "Look Who's Talking Now." She also starred in the film "Summer School" and played the lead role in the sitcom "Veronica's Closet," for which she won another Emmy Award.

In the 2000s, Alley appeared in several reality television shows, including "Fat Actress," a semi-autobiographical sitcom that aired on Showtime, and "Kirstie Alley's Big Life," a reality show that aired on A&E. She also competed on the 12th season of "Dancing with the Stars" and appeared on the British reality show "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!"

Personal Life
--------------

### Body Image

Alley has been open about her struggles with weight and body image throughout her career. She has appeared on the cover of several tabloids and has been the subject of much speculation and criticism regarding her weight. In 2004, she appeared on the cover of People magazine, weighing 145 pounds and declaring that she had finally achieved her ideal weight.

However, Alley's weight struggles continued, and she gained back much of the weight she had lost. In 2010, she appeared on the reality show "Kirstie Alley's Big Life," which documented her struggles with weight and her efforts to lose weight.

### Scientology

Alley is a longtime member of the Church of Scientology and has credited the church with helping her to overcome her struggles with addiction and weight. She has appeared in several promotional videos for the church and has spoken publicly about the benefits of Scientology.

### Politics

Alley has been open about her conservative politics and has supported several Republican candidates, including John McCain and Newt Gingrich. In 2012, she endorsed Mitt Romney for president and appeared at a campaign rally on his behalf.

Kirstie Alley died on December 5, 2022, at the age of 71, after a long battle with colon cancer.

article:
Renaissance (BeyoncÃ© album)

Renaissance is the seventh studio album by American singer BeyoncÃ©, released on July 29, 2022, through Parkwood Entertainment and Columbia Records. The album marks BeyoncÃ©'s first solo studio album in six years, following the release of Lemonade in 2016.

# Background and conception

BeyoncÃ© began working on Renaissance in 2018, shortly after giving birth to her twins, Rumi and Sir. The album's conception was influenced by the COVID-19 pandemic, which caused BeyoncÃ© to re-evaluate her priorities and focus on her music. She has stated that the album was inspired by her experiences as a mother, wife, and artist, and that she aimed to create a body of work that would inspire and uplift her audience.

Renaissance was recorded over a period of three years, with BeyoncÃ© working with a variety of collaborators, including producers, songwriters, and musicians. The album's sound is characterized by its fusion of different genres, including Afrobeats, house, disco, and hip-hop.

# Cover artwork

The cover artwork for Renaissance features a photograph of BeyoncÃ© riding a horse, taken by photographer Carlijn Jacobs. The image is a reference to the work of artist John Collier, who painted a series of works featuring women riding horses in the early 20th century. BeyoncÃ© has stated that she chose the image because it represents her desire to reclaim and reappropriate traditional symbols of power and strength.

# Composition

Renaissance is a concept album that explores themes of love, identity, and empowerment. The album's sound is characterized by its use of lush instrumentation, intricate vocal arrangements, and innovative production techniques. The album features a range of collaborators, including Jay-Z, Drake, and Tems, among others.

The album's tracklist is divided into two sections: Act I and Act II. Act I features a series of upbeat tracks, including the album's lead single, "Break My Soul," and the Afrobeats-inspired "I'm That Girl." Act II features a series of more introspective tracks, including the ballad "Church Girl" and the experimental "Alien Superstar."

# Promotion and release

## Singles

Renaissance was preceded by the release of two singles: "Break My Soul" and "Cuff It." "Break My Soul" was released in June 2022 and debuted at number one on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. "Cuff It" was released in August 2022 and peaked at number 13 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart.

## Tour

BeyoncÃ© announced the Renaissance World Tour in February 2023, with dates scheduled in North America, Europe, and Australia. The tour features a series of high-profile opening acts, including Kendrick Lamar and The Weeknd.

## Visuals

BeyoncÃ© released a series of visuals to accompany the album's release, including music videos for "Break My Soul" and "Cuff It." The videos feature BeyoncÃ© performing the songs in a variety of elaborate settings, including a disco and a fashion shoot.

## Renaissance Couture

BeyoncÃ© launched a fashion line, Renaissance Couture, in collaboration with Adidas, to coincide with the album's release. The line features a range of clothing and accessories, including dresses, tops, and shoes.

# Reception

## Critical response

Renaissance received widespread critical acclaim upon its release. Reviewers praised the album's innovative production, BeyoncÃ©'s vocal performances, and the album's thematic coherence. The album holds a Metacritic score of 91 out of 100, based on 32 reviews.

## Featured, sampled and interpolated artists

Renaissance features a range of collaborators, including Jay-Z, Drake, and Tems, among others. The album also samples and interpolates the work of a number of artists, including Donna Summer, Giorgio Moroder, and Afrika Bambaataa.

# Accolades

## Awards

Renaissance won the Grammy Award for Best Dance/Electronic Album in 2023. The album was also nominated for Album of the Year and Best Urban Contemporary Album.

## Year-end rankings

Renaissance was ranked as one of the best albums of 2022 by a number of publications, including Rolling Stone, Pitchfork, and The New York Times.

# Commercial performance

## United States

Renaissance debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart, with sales of 332,000 copies in its first week. The album spent three weeks at number one on the chart and was certified triple platinum by the RIAA in 2023.

## Internationally

Renaissance reached number one on the album charts in a number of countries, including the UK, Australia, and Canada. The album was certified platinum in the UK and double platinum in Australia.

# Legacy

Renaissance has been credited with influencing a new generation of artists and producers. The album's innovative production and thematic coherence have been praised by critics and fans alike.

article:
Sardar (2022 film)

Sardar is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language spy thriller film written and directed by P. S. Mithran. The film stars Karthi, Raashii Khanna, Rajisha Vijayan, and Chunky Pandey in lead roles. Produced by S. Lakshman Kumar under the banner of Prince Pictures, Sardar follows the story of a spy who must navigate a complex web of espionage and deceit to uncover the truth.

# Plot

The film begins with Inspector Vijay (Karthi) being introduced as a struggling cop who is unable to solve any cases. However, it is soon revealed that Vijay is actually a spy working for the Indian government, using his cover as a police officer to gather intelligence. Vijay's latest mission is to infiltrate a terrorist organization that is planning to disrupt the Indian economy.

As Vijay delves deeper into the organization, he meets Advocate Shalini (Raashii Khanna) who is also working undercover to gather evidence against the terrorists. The two form an alliance and work together to uncover the truth behind the terrorist plot.

Meanwhile, Vijay's past is slowly revealed through a series of flashbacks. It is shown that Vijay's father, Chandrasekhar (also played by Karthi), was a renowned spy who was killed in action. Vijay's desire for revenge against his father's killers drives him to become a spy himself.

As the story unfolds, Vijay and Shalini discover that the terrorist plot is more complex than they initially thought. They must use all their skills and resources to stay one step ahead of the terrorists and prevent a catastrophic attack.

# Cast

* Karthi as Inspector Vijay / Chandrasekhar
* Raashii Khanna as Advocate Shalini
* Rajisha Vijayan as Nisha
* Chunky Pandey as Sharma
* Laila as Siva's wife
* Murali Sharma as Colonel
* Avanthika Mohan as Chandrasekhar's wife
* Suresh Chandra Menon as DIG
* Balaji Sakthivel as Siva

# Production

## Development

The film was first announced in November 2020, with Karthi and Raashii Khanna attached to star. P. S. Mithran was roped in to direct the film, which was produced by S. Lakshman Kumar under the banner of Prince Pictures.

## Casting

Karthi was the first actor to be cast in the film, playing the dual role of Inspector Vijay and Chandrasekhar. Raashii Khanna was later cast as the female lead, playing the role of Advocate Shalini. Rajisha Vijayan and Chunky Pandey were also cast in supporting roles.

## Filming

Principal photography began in January 2021 and took place in various locations in India and abroad. The film's cinematography was handled by George C. Williams, while the editing was done by Ruben.

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by G. V. Prakash Kumar, with lyrics written by Pa. Vijay and Madhan Karky. The album consists of five tracks, including the title track "Sardar".

# Release

## Theatrical

Sardar was released theatrically on October 21, 2022, in Tamil Nadu and other parts of India. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification.

## Distribution

The film's distribution rights were acquired by Prince Pictures, which also produced the film. The film was released in over 500 theaters across India.

## Home media

The film's satellite rights were sold to Sun TV, while the digital rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video. The film was made available for streaming on Amazon Prime Video on November 18, 2022.

# Reception

Sardar received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising Karthi's performance and the film's engaging storyline. The film was also a commercial success, grossing over â‚¹100 crore at the box office.

# Sequel

In November 2022, it was announced that a sequel to Sardar was in the works, with Karthi and P. S. Mithran set to reprise their roles. The sequel is expected to begin production in 2023.

article:
Climate change mitigation refers to the actions taken to reduce the severity of climate change by decreasing the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. These efforts can be implemented at various levels, from individual to global, and involve a range of strategies, including reducing energy consumption, increasing the use of renewable energy sources, and preserving and enhancing natural carbon sinks.

# Definitions and scope

Climate change mitigation is a critical component of addressing climate change, as it can help to reduce the severity of its impacts and avoid the most catastrophic consequences. Mitigation efforts can be categorized into two main types: reducing greenhouse gas emissions and removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

## Relationship with solar radiation modification (SRM)

Solar radiation modification (SRM) is a proposed approach to mitigate climate change by reflecting a small percentage of the sun's radiation back into space. While SRM is not a substitute for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, it could potentially be used in conjunction with mitigation efforts to help achieve temperature targets.

# Emission trends and pledges

Despite growing awareness of the importance of addressing climate change, greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise. Current country pledges to reduce emissions are insufficient to limit warming to 1.5Â°C above pre-industrial levels.

## Needed emissions cuts

To achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement, global emissions must be reduced by 45% by 2030 compared to 2010 levels. This requires significant transformations in the way energy is produced, consumed, and distributed.

## Pledges

Countries have made varying levels of commitment to reducing emissions, with some pledging to achieve net-zero emissions by mid-century. However, current pledges are not sufficient to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement, and more ambitious action is needed.

# Low-carbon energy

Transitioning to low-carbon energy sources is a critical component of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

## Solar and wind energy

Solar and wind energy are two of the fastest-growing sources of new power generation capacity worldwide. These renewable energy sources offer significant potential for reducing emissions and improving energy security.

## Other renewables

Other renewable energy sources, such as hydroelectric power, geothermal energy, and biomass, also play important roles in reducing emissions.

## Integrating variable renewable energy

As the share of variable renewable energy sources in the energy mix increases, grid operators and policymakers must work to ensure that the grid remains resilient and reliable.

## Nuclear power

Nuclear power is a low-carbon energy source that can provide baseload power. However, its development is often hindered by high upfront costs and public concerns about safety and waste disposal.

## Replacing coal with natural gas

Replacing coal with natural gas can lead to significant emissions reductions in the short term. However, natural gas is not a long-term solution to climate change, and its development must be accompanied by measures to reduce methane leakage.

# Demand reduction

Reducing energy demand is critical to achieving emissions reductions.

## Energy conservation and efficiency

Improving energy efficiency in buildings, industry, and transportation can lead to significant emissions reductions.

## Lifestyle changes

Individuals can make lifestyle changes, such as reducing meat consumption, using public transportation, and increasing energy efficiency in their homes, to contribute to emissions reductions.

## Dietary change

Animal agriculture is a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions. Reducing meat consumption, particularly beef, can lead to significant emissions reductions.

## Family size

Family planning and education can help reduce population growth, which is a driver of greenhouse gas emissions.

# Preserving and enhancing carbon sinks

Preserving and enhancing natural carbon sinks, such as forests, soils, and wetlands, is critical to removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

## Forests

### Conservation

Conserving existing forests is critical to maintaining carbon sinks.

### Afforestation and reforestation

Planting new trees can help restore degraded forests and expand carbon sinks.

## Soils

Soil conservation and restoration can help sequester carbon in soils.

## Wetlands

Wetlands, such as mangroves and salt marshes, are important carbon sinks.

## Deep ocean

The deep ocean is a significant carbon sink, and its preservation is critical to maintaining ocean health.

## Enhanced weathering

Enhanced weathering involves adding minerals to soils and oceans to enhance carbon sequestration.

# Other methods to capture and store CO2

Other methods, such as direct air capture and carbon capture and storage, can also be used to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

# Mitigation by sector

Different sectors, such as buildings, transportation, and industry, require unique approaches to mitigation.

## Buildings

Improving energy efficiency in buildings, through measures such as insulation and efficient appliances, can lead to significant emissions reductions.

## Urban planning

Urban planning can play a critical role in reducing emissions, through measures such as designing compact cities and promoting public transportation.

## Transport

### Shipping

Improving fuel efficiency and transitioning to low-carbon fuels can reduce emissions from shipping.

### Air transport

Improving fuel efficiency and transitioning to low-carbon fuels can reduce emissions from air transport.

## Agriculture, forestry and land use

Sustainable land use practices, such as agroforestry and permaculture, can help sequester carbon and reduce emissions.

## Industry

Improving energy efficiency and transitioning to low-carbon production processes can reduce emissions from industry.

# Co-benefits

Mitigation efforts can have co-benefits, such as improving energy security, public health, and economic development.

## Employment and economic development

Mitigation efforts can create new job opportunities and stimulate local economies.

## Energy security

Reducing dependence on fossil fuels can improve energy security.

## Health and well-being

Reducing air pollution from fossil fuels can improve public health and well-being.

## Climate change adaptation

Mitigation efforts can also help communities adapt to the impacts of climate change.

# Negative side effects

Mitigation efforts can have negative side effects, such as increased costs and land use changes.

# Costs and funding

Mitigation efforts require significant funding, which can be challenging to secure.

## Avoided costs of climate change effects

The costs of climate change impacts, such as sea-level rise and extreme weather events, can be avoided through mitigation efforts.

## Distributing emissions abatement costs

The costs of mitigation efforts can be distributed fairly, through measures such as carbon pricing.

## Funding

Funding for mitigation efforts can come from a variety of sources, including government, private sector, and multilateral institutions.

# Policies

Policies, such as carbon pricing and regulations, can support mitigation efforts.

## National policies

### Carbon pricing

Carbon pricing, such as through carbon taxes or cap-and-trade systems, can provide a financial incentive for reducing emissions.

## International agreements

### Paris Agreement

The Paris Agreement is an international agreement that aims to limit warming to 1.5Â°C above pre-industrial levels.

# History

Climate change mitigation efforts have a long history, dating back to the 1970s.

# Society and culture

Climate change mitigation efforts can be influenced by societal and cultural factors, such as public awareness and education.

## Commitments to divest

Divestment from fossil fuel companies has become a growing trend, particularly among universities and pension funds.

## Barriers

Barriers to mitigation efforts, such as lack of public awareness and policy support, can hinder progress.

## Impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has had significant impacts on mitigation efforts, including reduced emissions and increased focus on public health.

# Examples by country

Different countries have made varying levels of commitment to mitigation efforts.

## United States

The United States has made significant progress on mitigation efforts, particularly at the state and local level.

## China

China has made significant progress on mitigation efforts, particularly in the area of renewable energy.

## European Union

The European Union has made significant progress on mitigation efforts, particularly in the area of carbon pricing.

2023 CONCACAF U-17 Championship

The 2023 CONCACAF U-17 Championship is the 19th edition of the CONCACAF U-17 Championship, the men's under-17 international football tournament organized by CONCACAF. The tournament will determine the four CONCACAF representatives at the 2023 FIFA U-17 World Cup in Indonesia.

# Qualified teams

A total of 20 teams will participate in the tournament. The teams were determined by the CONCACAF Council, with the top three teams from the 2022 CONCACAF U-17 Championship qualifying directly, along with the host nation. The remaining 16 teams were determined through a qualifying tournament, with the top two teams from each of the three groups qualifying.
